abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third Agriculture
            Rehabilitation Project (ARP III) for Timor Leste were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk
            to development outcome was substantial, Bank performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance was also
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: 1)
            for proper monitoring of project progress and to take
            corrective measures during implementation, a proper
            monitoring and evaluation (M&E) system should be
            designed and instituted at the earliest, especially for
            less-than-ideal conditions for implementation. In
            particular, more technical assistance and regular
            independent technical reviews are required from the start,
            given difficulties in systematically gathering and analyzing
            data; 2) when one of the major impacts of the project is to
            increase rice yields in irrigated areas, activities related
            to crop production should have been included under ARP III.
            Along with water, other inputs such as improved seeds, as
            well as introduction of an improved package of practices for
            irrigated agriculture, are necessary for increasing crop
            yields; 3) it is important at this stage to focus on
            irrigation system maintenance and management rather than new
            construction given current capacity constraints. For
            accruing optimal benefits from rehabilitated irrigation
            schemes, attention should be given to the irrigation canal
            network designs including establishing equity in water
            service delivery over the entire command area with the help
            of topographical surveys and ensuring timely maintenance of
            the scheme; and 4) the difficulties in obtaining reliable
            information and the constantly changing environment make it
            difficult to conduct supervision in a traditional way. A
            closer monitoring of project activities and impact with
            constant dialogue with Government through a field presence
            should be considered. Sufficient supervision resources for
            providing this level of support will be paramount.
